description: From Middle English oppressen, from Old French oppresser, from Medieval Latin oppressare (“to press against, oppress”), frequentative of Latin opprimere, past participle oppressus (“to press against, press together, oppress”), from ob (“against”) + premere, past participle pressus (“to press”); see press.

verbs.description: oppress (third-person singular simple present oppresses, present participle oppressing, simple past and past participle oppressed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To keep down by unjust force.
examples: The rural poor were oppressed by the land-owners.
We were oppressed by the constant grey skies.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) Physically to press down on (someone) with harmful effects; to smother, crush.
